Rubilar reconoce que carabineros "están cansados" y descarta violación "sistemática" de DD.HH.
"Para plantear que hay violaciones sistemáticas a los derechos humanos eso significa que hubo una orden y eso quiero ser categórica, no ha ocurrido", dijo la vocera de Gobierno.
07 Nov 2019 by Francisco Espinoza
La vocera de Gobierno, Karla Rubilar, descartó que existan violaciones "sistemáticas" de los derechos humanos y que los abusos cometidos por Carabineros corresponden a policías "que se salen del protocolo".
"Para plantear que hay violaciones sistemáticas a los derechos humanos eso significa que hubo una orden y eso quiero ser categórica, no ha ocurrido (…) Siempre las instrucciones que se dan por parte del estado son respetar los derechos humanos, y hay protocolos del uso de la fuerza y eso es lo que se tiene que respetar. Lo que nos ha pasado es que algunos no cumplieron esos protocolos", dijo.
"Con mucha honestidad, hay que decir que cada uno de los funcionarios que se salen del protocolo, cometen abusos o uso excesivo de la fuerza, o delitos tienen que ser condenados con la mayor fuerza. Tienen que iniciarse acciones administrativas, penales", agregó.
Además, la jefa del gobierno regional reconoció que, tras tres semanas de protestas sociales, "Carabineros está al límite".
"Yo quiero ser honesta: están cansados", dijo.
"Estamos teniendo dificultades con las herramientas actuales que tiene carabineros y la pdi para poder enfrentar este nivel de violencia de grupos menores, pero organizados", agregó.
text:
Rubilar acknowledges that carabineros "are tired" and dismisses "systematic" violation of DD.HH.
"To state that there are systematic violations of human rights that means that there was an order and that I want to be categorical has not happened," said the spokeswoman for the Government.
07 Nov 2019 by Francisco Espinoza
The spokeswoman for the Government, Karla Rubilar, ruled out that there are "systematic" violations of human rights and that the abuses committed by police officers correspond to police officers "who leave the protocol."
"To state that there are systematic violations of human rights that means that there was an order and that I want to be categorical, it has not happened (...) Always the instructions given by the state are to respect human rights, and there are protocols of use of force and that is what has to be respected. What has happened to us is that some did not comply with those protocols, "he said.
"With great honesty, it must be said that each of the officials who leave the protocol, commit abuses or excessive use of force, or crimes have to be convicted with the greatest force. Administrative, criminal actions have to be initiated." .
In addition, the head of the regional government acknowledged that, after three weeks of social protests, "Carabineros is at the limit."
"I want to be honest: they are tired," he said.
"We are having difficulties with the current tools that the police and the IDP have in order to face this level of violence from smaller but organized groups," he added.
